DR. LOUIS FINKELSTEIN

The senior class will elect a president, vice-president, secretary, treasurer and sergeant-at-arms on Thursday and Friday, October 21 and 22.
"The ballot box will be open from
10.30 a. m. to 4.30 p. m.," announced
William B. Kempton, president of the
Student Council.
The rule is that senior class officers are to be elected on the third
week in October, junior officers the
last week in October, sophomore on
the first week in

November, and

freshman on the second week.

RABBI COMMENCES
CONFERENCE SERIES
Dr. Finkelstein To Speak
Monday On History
Of Judaism
Opening a series of eighteen lectures sponsored jointly by the University and the Baltimore Round
Table of the National Conference
of Jews and Christians, Dr. Louis
Finkelstein, prominent scholar and
rabbi, will lecture on "The History
of Judaism," Monday night at 8.15
at the Levering Hall Auditorium,
Dr. Finkelstein is at present Professor of Theology at the Jewish
Theological
Seminary, and
also
serves as Provost. He is a graduate
of City College of New York, receiving his Ph.D. degree at Columbia
University in 1918, and graduated
from the Jewish Seminary in 1919.
From 1928-1930, he served as President of the Rabbinical Assembly of
America. He is also a Fellow of the
American Academy of Jewish Research, Member of the Executive
Council of the United Synagogue,
and a member of the Hillel Foundation Commission of the Binai.Birith.

Twenty Students Answer Call
More than twenty Johns Hopkins
students heeded the News-LErrea's
call for candidates for its editorial
positions at a meeting last Monday
afternoon. Considering it only a fair
turnout, Stanley M. Finkel '38 editor, said that there was much room
for improvement and "we would like
to see many more out for the staff."
Finkel addressed the candidates at
the meeting and made it known that
in the near future classes in newswriting for beginners would begin.

athletic plan.

HULLABALOO PLANS
FOR COMING YEAR
Stress in this year's Hullabaloo
will be laid on pictures rather than
"write-up," declared Editor Soifer
today. In answer to the current demand for books filled with pictures,
Soifer has chosen a theme for the
year-book somewhat similar to the
object of the magazine Life. Student activities and the normal life
of the University will occupy prominent places in the 1938 annual, and
by mixing the two, Soifer hopes to
give a candid portrayal of campus
life in the book.
Although the general theme and
the basic ideas behind the construction of the book are to be copied
from a nationally known magazine,
many of the methods of carrying out
this theme, as well as the treatment
of the methods, will be original.

Dr. Alan F. Guttmacher, Associate in Obstetrics at the Johns Hopkins Medical School, will give a
course in the College for Teachers,
entitled Advanced Biology. It will
deal with the social, legal, econotrdC,
and medical aspects of human biology, This course will be similar to
the course given last year under the
auspices of the America Student
Union, except that this one will be
much more intensive and will require
outside reading and papers. Biology
IT is a prerequisite of the course,
and it is open only to a limited numher of women students.
Dr. H. S Jennings, Director of the
Zoological Laboratory, and Dr. T.
M. Sonneborn, Associate in Zoology,
will offer a course in Reproduction,
Development, and Genetics of Proto.,:oa. It is to consist of laboratory
work and conferences, and serves as
an introduction to research in Protozoan Genetics.

TO WATCH
Tonight's gridiron spectacle will be
watched in the main for two reasons.
Last April the new athletic policy
was officially announced, but this will
be the first opportunity to see it in
actual operation. What success it
has will be interesting to observe.
The second opportunity afforded will
be a first hand look into Coach Mallonee's 1937 football eleven.
The squad is still an unknown
quantity. The defeat at the hands of
the Lehigh huskies is not to be taken
as any justification of the merits of
the team. Our first real test is

DR. LOUIS FINKELSTEIN

The senior class will elect a president, vice-president, secretary, treasurer and sergeant-at-arms on Thursday and Friday, October 21 and 22.
"The ballot box will be open from
10.30 a. m. to 4.30 p. m.," announced
William B. Kempton, president of the
Student Council.
The rule is that senior class officers are to be elected on the third
week in October, junior officers the
last week in October, sophomore on
the first week in

November, and

freshman on the second week.

RABBI COMMENCES
CONFERENCE SERIES
Dr. Finkelstein To Speak
Monday On History
Of Judaism
Opening a series of eighteen lectures sponsored jointly by the University and the Baltimore Round
Table of the National Conference
of Jews and Christians, Dr. Louis
Finkelstein, prominent scholar and
rabbi, will lecture on "The History
of Judaism," Monday night at 8.15
at the Levering Hall Auditorium,
Dr. Finkelstein is at present Professor of Theology at the Jewish
Theological
Seminary, and
also
serves as Provost. He is a graduate
of City College of New York, receiving his Ph.D. degree at Columbia
University in 1918, and graduated
from the Jewish Seminary in 1919.
From 1928-1930, he served as President of the Rabbinical Assembly of
America. He is also a Fellow of the
American Academy of Jewish Research, Member of the Executive
Council of the United Synagogue,
and a member of the Hillel Foundation Commission of the Binai.Birith.

Twenty Students Answer Call
More than twenty Johns Hopkins
students heeded the News-LErrea's
call for candidates for its editorial
positions at a meeting last Monday
afternoon. Considering it only a fair
turnout, Stanley M. Finkel '38 editor, said that there was much room
for improvement and "we would like
to see many more out for the staff."
Finkel addressed the candidates at
the meeting and made it known that
in the near future classes in newswriting for beginners would begin.

HULLABALOO PLANS
FOR COMING YEAR
Stress in this year's Hullabaloo
will be laid on pictures rather than
"write-up," declared Editor Soifer
today. In answer to the current demand for books filled with pictures,
Soifer has chosen a theme for the
year-book somewhat similar to the
object of the magazine Life. Student activities and the normal life
of the University will occupy prominent places in the 1938 annual, and
by mixing the two, Soifer hopes to
give a candid portrayal of campus
life in the book.
Although the general theme and
the basic ideas behind the construction of the book are to be copied
from a nationally known magazine,
many of the methods of carrying out
this theme, as well as the treatment
of the methods, will be original.

Dr. Alan F. Guttmacher, Associate in Obstetrics at the Johns Hopkins Medical School, will give a
course in the College for Teachers,
entitled Advanced Biology. It will
deal with the social, legal, econotrdC,
and medical aspects of human biology, This course will be similar to
the course given last year under the
auspices of the America Student
Union, except that this one will be
much more intensive and will require
outside reading and papers. Biology
IT is a prerequisite of the course,
and it is open only to a limited numher of women students.
Dr. H. S Jennings, Director of the
Zoological Laboratory, and Dr. T.
M. Sonneborn, Associate in Zoology,
will offer a course in Reproduction,
Development, and Genetics of Proto.,:oa. It is to consist of laboratory
work and conferences, and serves as
an introduction to research in Protozoan Genetics.

TWO THINGS
TO WATCH
Tonight's gridiron spectacle will be
watched in the main for two reasons.
Last April the new athletic policy
was officially announced, but this will
be the first opportunity to see it in
actual operation. What success it
has will be interesting to observe.
The second opportunity afforded will
be a first hand look into Coach Mallonee's 1937 football eleven.
The squad is still an unknown
quantity. The defeat at the hands of
the Lehigh huskies is not to be taken
as any justification of the merits of
the team. Our first real test is
Washington College.
